segment.source: Create an Inbound Port Rule (Windows 10)
segment.target: Create an Inbound Port Rule (Windows 10)

segment.source: Create an Inbound Port Rule
segment.target: Create an Inbound Port Rule

segment.source: Create an Inbound Port Rule
segment.target: Create an Inbound Port Rule

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview
segment.target: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview

segment.source: To allow inbound network traffic on only a specified TCP or UDP port number, use the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security node in the Group Policy Management MMC snap-in to create firewall rules.
segment.target: To allow inbound network traffic on only a specified TCP or UDP port number, use the Windows Firewall with Advanced Security node in the Group Policy Management MMC snap-in to create firewall rules.

segment.source: This type of rule allows any program that listens on a specified TCP or UDP port to receive network traffic sent to that port.
segment.target: This type of rule allows any program that listens on a specified TCP or UDP port to receive network traffic sent to that port.

segment.source: Administrative credentials
segment.target: Administrative credentials

segment.source: To complete these procedures, you must be a member of the Domain Administrators group, or otherwise be delegated permissions to modify the GPOs.
segment.target: To complete these procedures, you must be a member of the Domain Administrators group, or otherwise be delegated permissions to modify the GPOs.

segment.source: This topic describes how to create a standard port rule for a specified protocol or TCP or UDP port number.
segment.target: This topic describes how to create a standard port rule for a specified protocol or TCP or UDP port number.

segment.source: For other inbound port rule types, see:
segment.target: For other inbound port rule types, see:

segment.source: Create an Inbound ICMP Rule
segment.target: Create an Inbound ICMP Rule

segment.source: Create Inbound Rules to Support RPC
segment.target: Create Inbound Rules to Support RPC

segment.source: To create an inbound port rule
segment.target: To create an inbound port rule

segment.source: Open the Group Policy Management Console to Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.
segment.target: Open the Group Policy Management Console to Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.

segment.source: In the navigation pane, click Inbound Rules.
segment.target: In the navigation pane, click Inbound Rules.

segment.source: Click Action, and then click New rule.
segment.target: Click Action, and then click New rule.

segment.source: On the Rule Type page of the New Inbound Rule Wizard, click Custom, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Rule Type page of the New Inbound Rule Wizard, click Custom, and then click Next.

segment.source: Note: Although you can create rules by selecting Program or Port, those choices limit the number of pages presented by the wizard.
segment.target: Note: Although you can create rules by selecting Program or Port, those choices limit the number of pages presented by the wizard.

segment.source: If you select Custom, you see all of the pages, and have the most flexibility in creating your rules.
segment.target: If you select Custom, you see all of the pages, and have the most flexibility in creating your rules.

segment.source: On the Program page, click All programs, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Program page, click All programs, and then click Next.

segment.source: Note: This type of rule is often combined with a program or service rule.
segment.target: Note: This type of rule is often combined with a program or service rule.

segment.source: If you combine the rule types, you get a firewall rule that limits traffic to a specified port and allows the traffic only when the specified program is running.
segment.target: If you combine the rule types, you get a firewall rule that limits traffic to a specified port and allows the traffic only when the specified program is running.

segment.source: The specified program cannot receive network traffic on other ports, and other programs cannot receive network traffic on the specified port.
segment.target: The specified program cannot receive network traffic on other ports, and other programs cannot receive network traffic on the specified port.

segment.source: If you choose to do this, follow the steps in the Create an Inbound Program or Service Rule procedure in addition to the steps in this procedure to create a single rule that filters network traffic using both program and port criteria.
segment.target: If you choose to do this, follow the steps in the Create an Inbound Program or Service Rule procedure in addition to the steps in this procedure to create a single rule that filters network traffic using both program and port criteria.

segment.source: On the Protocol and Ports page, select the protocol type that you want to allow.
segment.target: On the Protocol and Ports page, select the protocol type that you want to allow.

segment.source: To restrict the rule to a specified port number, you must select either TCP or UDP.
segment.target: To restrict the rule to a specified port number, you must select either TCP or UDP.

segment.source: Because this is an incoming rule, you typically configure only the local port number.
segment.target: Because this is an incoming rule, you typically configure only the local port number.

segment.source: If you select another protocol, then only packets whose protocol field in the IP header match this rule are permitted through the firewall.
segment.target: If you select another protocol, then only packets whose protocol field in the IP header match this rule are permitted through the firewall.

segment.source: To select a protocol by its number, select Custom from the list, and then type the number in the Protocol number box.
segment.target: To select a protocol by its number, select Custom from the list, and then type the number in the Protocol number box.

segment.source: When you have configured the protocols and ports, click Next.
segment.target: When you have configured the protocols and ports, click Next.

segment.source: On the Scope page, you can specify that the rule applies only to network traffic to or from the IP addresses entered on this page.
segment.target: On the Scope page, you can specify that the rule applies only to network traffic to or from the IP addresses entered on this page.

segment.source: Configure as appropriate for your design, and then click Next.
segment.target: Configure as appropriate for your design, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Action page, select Allow the connection, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Action page, select Allow the connection, and then click Next.

segment.source: On the Profile page, select the network location types to which this rule applies, and then click Next.
segment.target: On the Profile page, select the network location types to which this rule applies, and then click Next.

segment.source: Note: If this GPO is targeted at server computers running Windows Server 2008 that never move, consider modifying the rules to apply to all network location type profiles.
segment.target: Note: If this GPO is targeted at server computers running Windows Server 2008 that never move, consider modifying the rules to apply to all network location type profiles.

segment.source: This prevents an unexpected change in the applied rules if the network location type changes due to the installation of a new network card or the disconnection of an existing network card’s cable.
segment.target: This prevents an unexpected change in the applied rules if the network location type changes due to the installation of a new network card or the disconnection of an existing network card’s cable.

segment.source: A disconnected network card is automatically assigned to the Public network location type.
segment.target: A disconnected network card is automatically assigned to the Public network location type.

segment.source: On the Name page, type a name and description for your rule, and then click Finish.
segment.target: On the Name page, type a name and description for your rule, and then click Finish.
